Again, though, real world application tells a different story.

 My experience -
 
 Calgary is the center of Canada's oil patch, and with oil riding high, Calgary is seeing an unprecedented real estate boom. (When oil went in the tank in the mid-late 80s, you could buy entire subdivisions in Calgary for $1, just take over the mortgages and they were yours.)
 
 They can't build the houses fast enough. My brother, and my best friend both recently bought new houses, my brother's was about 2 years old, my friends was brand new. Both are way out on the outskirts of the city.
 
 I wouldn't pay half of what they paid, because the houses aren't worth it. They're structurally poor, sloppily built, and carelessly finished. They're modern, and they look great, from about 25'. Two year old houses on stable, well drained soil and bedrock, with cracks in the walls, and don't even get me started on the quality of the interior finish work. emoticon_mad 
 
 I've actually talked to several people in the trades, a couple of them lifelong friends, that will no longer work for the big home builders, their consciences won't let them, and nor will their pocket books. Cut every corner, work 16hrs/day for 10hrs pay, and be treated like dirt for your trouble. They've all moved into residential renovation or small commercial companies.
 
 I renovated the basement of our place myself, completely gutted it - 50 year old concrete, and not a single crack. The entire place is built out of 2X4 and 2X6 Fir, actual plywood, and real plaster and brick. The house will easily stand for another 50 years, with ZERO problems.
 
 Not to blow my own horn, but I bought in an inner city neighborhood, a 5-10 minute commute to downtown. I searched it out thoroughly and found a neighborhood that was just on the cusp of a major rejuventation. The houses are bungalows, modest homes from around 800-1200 sq ft, on 60'x120' lots, built in the mid '50s. The area is zoned R2, both good and bad. It will never be "prime", but the lots can be subdivided, and houses can be rented. As it stands, the homes in our area have increased at an approx. 20% higher rate than the average, and the tide of new infills is rapidly marching my way - $$$$$$..
 
 I'm relatively new to the game, but I've heard a lot of the horror stories from the guys that lived through the oil crashes of the 70's and 80's, and IMHO, it's not if, it's when will it happen again. There'll be a lot of people with some serious problems.

 P.S. - I've got a cousin that owns a hardware store/lumber yard, and he'll swear up and down that today's OSB is actually superior in every way to plywood. :)

As a daytrader I can give some tips:
 
 1. Always do your homework, don't ever slack off.
 
 2. Nobody is twisting your arm to trade. If you don't feel right in the head or the market just doesn't look right, don't trade. No profit is still better than a loss.
 
 3. Never short in a high volume bull market.
 
 4. Cut your losses when you're down. A small loss is better than a possible profit which might never materialise. Hope kills, never hope. 
 
 5. Know that you know very little. Only the marketmakers know the real deal.
 
 6. Emotion has no place when daytrading, turn it off.
 
 7. Always pay close attention to when Greenspan speaks. Try not to trade that day.

I own controlling stake in a residential construction company, and partial stake in a couple others. they primarily service suburban real estate markets, building sawdust and cardboard mc mansions that are sold for $150,000-$500,000. when i built my own house, I did NOT have anybody that works for me do it, I found a local contractor. My guys are used to tossing up mc mansions to be sold to XXXXXX. I did not want anything they would have built.
 
 The problem with modern buiulding mateirals is that they perform GREAT in a lab, but not so well in the real world. You take a piece of OSB, uncut, and you can sink it to the bottom of the ocean, and in 10 years, it will still be there. Cut a piece of it, drop it in a bucket, and in 2 days you have a pile of floating wood chips. 
 
 Masonite siding is the same. Uncut, with the facotry seal, it will last forever. Drive the nail heads too deep (so you break the skin) and it is a 5 yr piece of siding. Miss caulking around a window, and it is a 3 yr piece of siding. I don't care....my warranty is 1 year.
 
 This is a pretty good time to be in the construction business, as people suck up cheaply built, high profit (for the builder) homes with interest only loans that they cannot afford to service if housing bubble bursts, and will drop drastically in re-sale at the first hint of trouble, becuase they are garbage to begin with.
